problem: Our club has $25$ members, and wishes to pick a president, secretary, and treasurer. In how many ways can we choose the officers, if individual members are allowed to hold $2,$ but not all $3,$ offices?
solution:
With no restriction, the president can be any of the $25$ members, the secretary can be any of the $25$ remaining members, and the treasurer can be any of the remaining $25$ members.

If the same member holds all three offices, it could be any of the $25$ members, so there are $25$ ways for this to happen. We must exclude these $25$ possibilities, so the answer is $25\times 25\times 25-25=\boxed{15,600}.$
model_solution:
Step 1: We consider the number of ways to choose the officers, depending on the number of offices held by each member.
- (a) One member holds 2 offices, and the other 3 members hold 1 office each.
- (b) Two members hold 2 offices each, and the other 3 members hold 1 office each.
- (c) Three members hold 1 office each.
Step 2:
- (a) There are $\binom{25}{1}=25$ ways to choose the member who holds $2$ offices. There are $3$ ways to choose which offices this member holds, and $\binom{24}{3}=24\cdot 23\cdot 22$ ways to choose which offices the other $3$ members hold. Hence, there are $25\cdot 3\cdot 24\cdot 23\cdot 22$ ways to choose the officers for this case.
- (b) There are $\binom{25}{2}=300$ ways to choose the members who hold $2$ offices. There are $\frac{3!}{2!1!}=3$ ways to choose which offices these members hold, and $\binom{23}{1}=23$ ways to choose which office the remaining member holds. Hence, there are $300\cdot 3\cdot 23$ ways to choose the officers for this case.
- (c) There are $\binom{25}{3}=25\cdot 24\cdot 23$ ways to choose the members who hold $1$ office each. There are $3!$
Step 3:
- (c) There are $25\cdot 24\cdot 23\cdot 3!$ ways to choose the officers for this case.


Final Answer: The final answer is  $ \boxed{ 12,650}.$
